  physical_appearance: This is a lamp screen. It takes the shape of a rectangular box
 with panels of glass on the back
 right and left side. The top and back of the screen has decorative foliage carvings. The screen is painted red and gilded gold. The paint and gilding looks faded.

  subject_terms_1: ceremonial objects Peranakan religious ceremonies foliage (motif) altar components

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Rites and ceremonies Peranakan (Asian people) Screens Altars Ceremonial objects

  subject_terms_3: Religious life and practices

  sgcool_label_text: This lamp screen is made of wood painted red and gilded
 with three panels of glass. The screen is placed on the altar to house an oil lamp that would be lit on the altar during religious ceremonies or on special occasions like Chinese New Year.\r\n\r\nThis item is donated by the family of prominent Peranakan
 Ong Sam Leong (b. 1857
 Singapore – d. 7 February 1918
 Singapore). It comes from his ancestral home of Bukit Rose
 formerly at 259 Bukit Timah Road. Ong was a well-known successful businessman who made is money in the mining of phosphate on Christmas island
 which was historically a territory of colonial Singapore.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a lamp screen. It takes the shape of a rectangular box, with panels of glass on the back, right and left side. The top and back of the screen has decorative foliage carvings. The screen is painted red and gilded gold. The paint and gilding looks faded.
metadata.subject_terms_1: ceremonial objects Peranakan religious ceremonies foliage (motif) altar components
metadata.subject_terms_2: Motifs Rites and ceremonies Peranakan (Asian people) Screens Altars Ceremonial objects
metadata.sgcool_label_text:
This lamp screen is made of wood painted red and gilded, with three panels of glass. The screen is placed on the altar to house an oil lamp that would be lit on the altar during religious ceremonies or on special occasions like Chinese New Year.

This item is donated by the family of prominent Peranakan, Ong Sam Leong (b. 1857, Singapore – d. 7 February 1918, Singapore). It comes from his ancestral home of Bukit Rose, formerly at 259 Bukit Timah Road. Ong was a well-known successful businessman who made is money in the mining of phosphate on Christmas island, which was historically a territory of colonial Singapore.
